docs.snippet: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese won a federal injunction Monday that blocks a requirement of the new health care law to provide contraceptive care to employees at its nonprofit affiliates....
docs.abstract: Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is granted a federal injunction that blocks an Obama administration health law requirement to provide contraceptive care to employees at its nonprofit affiliates; ruling found that the regulation violated the religious freedom of the four nonprofit groups--two high schools and two health care systems.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese won a federal injunction Monday that blocks a requirement of the new health care law to provide contraceptive care to employees at its nonprofit affiliates.

headline.main: New York Archdiocese Wins Ruling on Contraception

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

docs.snippet: Judge Richard J. Leon is a conservative and a vivid writer who has criticized the federal government on pornography, death penalty drugs and terrorism suspects at Guantánamo Bay....
docs.abstract: Federal Judge Richard J Leon, who shook up Washington by declaring that National Security Agency's data collection program likely violates the Constitution, has a record of wrestling with thorny issues, and with the federal government.
docs.lead_paragraph: Judge Richard J. Leon is a conservative and a vivid writer who has criticized the federal government on pornography, death penalty drugs and terrorism suspects at Guantánamo Bay.

headline.print_headline: ‘Passionate’ Judge Has Record of Wrestling With Thorny Issues, and the U.S. Government
headline.main: Judge Has Record of Wrestling With Thorny Issues, and the U.S. Government

docs.snippet: Jacob Ostreicher, a Brooklyn flooring contractor who went to Bolivia to seek his fortune in rice farming but ended up being accused of laundering drug money, has been spirited out of the country, an assemblyman said....
docs.abstract: New York State Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn reports that Brooklyn flooring contractor Jacob Ostreicher, who was jailed in Bolivia for 18 months until the intervention of actor Sean Penn lessened his punishment to house arrest, has been spirited out of Bolivia and is in the New York area; Ostreicher went to Bolivia to seek his fortune in rice farming and ended up jailed accused of laundering drug money, charge he denies.
docs.lead_paragraph: Jacob Ostreicher, a Brooklyn flooring contractor who went to Bolivia to seek his fortune in rice farming but ended up being accused of laundering drug money, has been spirited out of the country, an assemblyman said.

headline.print_headline: Bolivian Jail, Actor’s Help, Now a Return To New York
headline.main: Bolivian Jail, an Actor’s Help and Now a Return to New York

docs.snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said three companies that serviced and financed high-interest online loans had violated federal laws as well as state ones....
docs.abstract: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau sues online loan servicer CashCall, two related companies and owner, J Paul Reddam, saying they serviced and financed high-interest online loans that violated federal laws as well as state ones.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said three companies that serviced and financed high-interest online loans had violated federal laws as well as state ones.

headline.print_headline: Federal Consumer Agency Sues Over Online Loans
headline.main: Federal Consumer Agency Sues Over Online Loans

docs.snippet: If they were once adversaries, bound by Mike Woodson’s fleeting plan for a playing-time showdown, Iman Shumpert and J. R. Smith have become poster boys for the Knicks’ troubles....
docs.abstract: Iman Shumpert and J R Smith have become poster boys for New York Knicks’ early-season trouble, as their only competition has been to determine who can struggle more; despite subterranean shooting numbers, both are surprisingly back in the starting lineup due to poor play by others and injuries.
docs.lead_paragraph: If they were once adversaries, bound by Mike Woodson’s fleeting plan for a playing-time showdown, Iman Shumpert and J. R. Smith have become poster boys for the Knicks’ troubles.

headline.print_headline: From Focal Points to Question Marks
headline.main: Knicks’ Smith and Shumpert Become Question Marks

docs.snippet: As President Obama considers his options on the surveillance of allies, damage to the United States’ relationship with Germany has proved difficult to repair....
docs.abstract: Effort to build a new intelligence relationship with Germany is foundering, nearly two months after Pres Obama assured Chancellor Angela Merkel that the United States would never again target her cellphone; American officials have refuse to extend the 'no spying' guarantee beyond Merkel.
docs.lead_paragraph: As President Obama considers his options on the surveillance of allies, damage to the United States’ relationship with Germany has proved difficult to repair.

headline.print_headline: U.S.-Germany Intelligence Partnership Falters Over Spying
headline.main: U.S.-Germany Intelligence Partnership Falters Over Spying

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and ALISON SMALE

docs.snippet: With 15 days left in office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be crisscrossing New York City’s five boroughs to highlight his administration’s successes....
docs.abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg is planning a five-borough farewell tour of New York City; with 15 days left in office, he plans to spend time highlighting his administration’s successes, and describing positive changes made since he took office in 2002.
docs.lead_paragraph: With 15 days left in office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be crisscrossing New York City’s five boroughs to highlight his administration’s successes.

headline.print_headline: Mayor Focuses On His Legacy In Farewell Tour Across the City
headline.main: Bloomberg Focuses on His Legacy in Farewell Tour Across the City

docs.snippet: A lawyer who called himself a philanthropist was sentenced to six years in a fraud case in which he cost insurance companies and bond insurers $46 million, a judge said....
docs.abstract: Joseph Caramadre, lawyer who called himself a philanthropist, is sentenced to six years in fraud case in which he cost insurance companies and bond insurers $46 million; federal prosecutors contend that Caramadre was a scam artist, preying on the ill and dying.
docs.lead_paragraph: A lawyer who called himself a philanthropist was sentenced to six years in a fraud case in which he cost insurance companies and bond insurers $46 million, a judge said.

headline.print_headline: Prison for Rhode Island Lawyer In Tale of Insurance and Death
headline.main: Prison for Rhode Island Lawyer in Tale of Insurance and Death

docs.snippet: Pope Francis, in naming bishops to a powerful Vatican committee, replaced a conservative American cardinal with another American considered more of a moderate on social issues....
docs.abstract: Pope Francis replaces conservative American Cardinal Raymond L Burke on the powerful Congregation for Bishops with Cardinal Donal Wuerl, who is less identified with the culture wars within the Roman Catholic Church; action regarding Burke, who has been an outspoken critic of abortion and same-sex marriage, is viewed by experts as another sign of Pope's commitment to inclusive agenda.
docs.lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, in naming bishops to a powerful Vatican committee, replaced a conservative American cardinal with another American considered more of a moderate on social issues.

headline.print_headline: Pope Replaces Conservative U.S. Cardinal on Influential Vatican Committee
headline.main: Pope Replaces Conservative U.S. Cardinal on Influential Vatican Committee

byline.contributor: Jim Yardley reported from Rome, and Jason Horowitz from Washington. Gaia Pianigiani contributed reporting from Rome, and Laurie Goodstein from New York.
byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY and JASON HOROWITZ

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

docs.snippet: Horses given the race-day medication furosemide bled at higher rates than those who were not, a study commissioned by the Breeders’ Cup found....
docs.abstract: Study released by Breeders' Cup shows that horses treated with the race-day antibleeding medication furosemide bled at a greater rate than horses that did not receive the drug; about 95 percent of American thoroughbreds race on furosemide, drug first approved for race-day use in the mid-1970s and sold under the brand name Lasix.
docs.lead_paragraph: Horses given the race-day medication furosemide bled at higher rates than those who were not, a study commissioned by the Breeders’ Cup found.

headline.print_headline: Study Raises Questions About Antibleeding Drug
headline.main: Study Raises Questions About Antibleeding Drug
